title: Courage of Colossus greatly overshadows Grasp of the Undying and Bond of Stone
body:
Even in Courage's nerfed state, it is still greatly more valuable than the other two. I'll seperate these into sections.

Bond of Stone 
Has such a marginal impact that you dont even know if its doing anything at all. Where in an average of a 30min game, you'll be lucky if it redirects even 500 damage total. That is an average of 16 damage blocked per minute. And the initial of 4% damage reduction for yourself is also non existent where it can be taken out of the game without anyone noticing the changes. 

Grasp of Undying
It had it's  limelight when it both dealt and healed for 3% of your maximum health. Yes it was strong for it's time but with the introduction of Courage, it marginalizes it's purpose. Grasp was supposed to help tanks sustain throughout the lane phase and help those who lacked in damage. However nerfing that sustain away makes Courage all the more valuable.

 In what circumstance would I ever want to choose Grasp or Bond over Courage? Is the issue that Courage is too strong or that the formers are too weak? Because I will be honest, I almost never used Grasp or Bond even before Courage came into play. I just find those keystones that weak.

replies.body:
Grasp was severely over-nerfed, and honestly affected laning more than late game, despite scaling. 

Bond of stone was over-nerfed and any support that might take it would rather take CoC. 

Both need to be replaced. 

_________

BoS is passive, unseen power, something Riot's crusaded against several times. 

Grasp grants damage+sustain for simply building health; something that ends up being must-have or too weak on any melee that builds HP.

I think Grasp could be reworked into something that provides sustain rather than pairing it with damage. Say you get an increased base HP regen buff for a few seconds, like a selfish Vorpal Blade.

Bond of stone should have a window of power. If the nearest ally sustains heavy damage and Bond of Stone is up, it could probably start redirecting damage heavily to you, mitigation considered. If your carry wasn't one-shot, you have a chance to save them, at the cost of being able to do it again for a while.

I think this is similar to what happened with Thunderlord's Decree a while back. Riot tuned over several patches, and it became strong on LITERALLY EVERY CHAMP. Riot nerfed Thunderlord's, but what really achieved balance was the reworks of the other keystone masteries: Windspeaker's and Stormraider's got buffed, and the ferocity keystones went through several iterations of rework. I like CoC where it is now, maybe needs a slight nerf, but really I think Grasp and Bond of Stone need buffs to bring balance.

Agreed. CoC isn't the problem, it's the other two. 

I like what Bond does right now, but it needs more, similar to how windspeaker's got to add MR and armor in addition to buffing heals/shields. There's nothing that says you can't have multiple effects on one keystone.

Honestly, Bond needs to be removed. It has the typical [Aura issue
](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/gameplay/road-pre-season-gameplay-systems-update)

> On the other hand, it can be hard to notice the impact of an aura. As a result, auras have ended up overtuned to the point where they become mandatory


And simply doesn't feel satisfying. Also, who is supposed to get it? The other tank masteries feel much more satisfying and there isn't really any champion that couldn't run one of the others. In my opinion we need some tank jgl mastery, as it is right now tank junglers take some mastery they don't really use most of the time in the early game, which isn't exactly satisfying either. Maybe a damage reflection mastery that works on monsters? It wouldn't be abused by non-tanks and it isn't appealing to laners (assuming it's tuned properly).

What if it got a more noticeable, windowed effect? Something like "if a nearby ally takes X% of their max health in damage over Y amount of time, you create a bond with them and absorb Z% (like, 20+) of the damage they take for 5-ish seconds. 30 second cooldown"

Really impactful and noticeable (with a really clear "bond" animation - something like Kalista's bond), but not constantly active.

i have always thought BoS needed a serious rework, and I think you're going in the right direction, but I find this a little too reactive. Even Grasp requires you to be in combat and attack. To me, a mastery should be something the player _decides to use_ not something you keep around in case your duo partner gets attacked. Like if you and a nearby ally deal damage within .5 seconds of each other, you each get extra resistances for a second or two? Long CD to make it valuable

That probably requires too much coordination to be feasible. Since Bond of Stone is meant for Warden-type tanks, it would need to be activated by something Wardens want to be doing. That makes it tough for it to be a proactive activation, though...

Enchanters work because they can target allies with heals and shields, but Wardens are more difficult, since generally they don't target their allies... They want to protect their carries and keep the enemy off of them, which they usually do through CC. It could be another CC activation, but I don't know how well people would receive that.

It could be the opposite of Courage of the Colossus - when you CC an enemy, nearby allies gain a shield and increased armor/mr for a few seconds (small radius for the shield, so it only works if you're guarding your team). Or just a strong damage reduction instead of the shield, plus maybe movement speed? It might need to activate on slows, as well as hard CC, though.

Yeah, CoC definitely fills the Warden tank niche well now, Bond of Stone might need to go back to the drawing board. It had a place in the original release of new masteries, but now it doesn't feel relevant. I'm trying to think what would flesh out the Resolve tree: we have long-term tank-sustain, CC-engage, what would make sense as a third? Clearly Riot was going for support tanks being able to keep their ADC alive, but in practice it falls short of feeling relevant.
Yea but thats because bond of trash and grasp of the underpants are lame and weak

Exaggeration on the shield bit but lets actually look at the deets first before looking at flat numbers.

1. the shield is based on how many people are around you, which means it is only really effective if you are engaging in some way.
2. the shield's cooldown is high, which means it isn't gonna help you beyond said initiation.
3. because most champs getting it will either be in solo lanes or the support, and thus the shield isn't used to its fullest yet, especially in the jungle, it is far less effective in lane than either bond or Grasp at this stage of the game.

In extended teamfights, Grasp IS better because it allows you to get more overall effective health than CoC does on a more consistent basis.  

Mid game you typically aren't even getting the full shield off, you are typically getting at best a 2 person shield value.
Grasp heals and damages based on time in combat, which doesn't have such a skewed consistentcy as all it requires is you auto a champ to proc it.

> because most champs getting it will either be in solo lanes or the support, and thus the shield isn't used to its fullest yet, especially in the jungle, it is far less effective in lane than either bond or Grasp at this stage of the game.

in lane CoC will probably be way better for trading in lane with it giving 20-190 hp + 5% max HP shield every 45-30 seconds which will probably be way more then 4% damage reduction

I'm not trying to use Grasp in a solo lane trading scenario because honesty who the heck would?
People getting Bond are in duo lanes. Plane and simple.

That said, it depends. If you ONLY trade in the window where CoC is up, which again, the cooloff for it lasts a long time, and the trade lasts only that duration, then yes. Otherwise, Grasp will actually be better. Because it can be stacked consistently by being in combat and can be proc'd by simply hitting someone once,

The actual Trade it does is also much more substantial in that one instant since it does bonus damage AND heals you base don said damage,

Lastly and most damming, unless your Hard CC is easy to apply, (point and click for example) you risk not even getting the shield when you trade if or when your enemy dodges it. Grasp doesn't have this issue.

CoC is good. Maybe even too good. But to claim that it makes the other two obsolete if you have any way to proc CoC is ludicrous.

If you are a champ that can easily and effortlessly proc it, then sure, but many champs would prefer Grasp.

While I'm not disagreeing with you I just want to say my opinion on this.  If you change Grasp to purely sustain then you might as well just give CoC to everyone because then their roles overlap a lot.  They both just help to reduce the damage you take in different ways.

I prefer Grasp as a damage mastery for the type of champions who simply want more damage and not yet another way to be tanky.  Otherwise if Grasp is going to heal you for 400 or CoC is going to shield you for 500+ (especially when multiple people are around and you get off your CC) then why ever take Grasp unless you absolutely cannot take CoC?  

Then that brings us back around to the exact same problem we already having.  So, you have to differentiate them somehow, and the only thing that separates Grasp is the damage.

We have nothing against a tank mastery being strong on tanks, but not only is the level of sustain making tanks immovable in lane, the damage turns them from CC bots to killing machines. Who are still CC bots.

This change probably won’t solve Grasp’s problems on its own, but we want to at least tone it down while we continue exploring our options."

Patch 6.12: "Despite our efforts earlier this season, Grasp of the Undying is still far too common in the top lane, crowding out other keystone masteries. The issue is that it's also very hard to appreciate. It's hard to notice 6%. Honestly, both of them feel weird. Wasn't {{item:3105}} stripped of its aura because auras were hard to appreciate? Knight's Vow and Bond of Stone both do something similar to an aura: an always-on effect (on a target) that's difficult to gauge what the range is and difficult to appreciate just how much mitigation it's doing for you.

Colossus is big and appreciable, you immediately see how much it does for you. Taric for example. What does he pick? Colossus because he has a (slightly unreliable) stun? Windspeaker for his W shield and Q heal? Bond of Stone? None of them are really amazing for Taric. He just picks "the best from what's available", but not "something that really augments my playstyle."
